metadata.title: Citrate-mediated sol–gel synthesis of Al-substituted sulfated zirconia catalysts for α-pinene isomerization

Rabee a b Lee J. Durndell b Nasr E. Fouad a Lucia Frattini b Mark A. Isaacs b Adam F. Lee b Gamal A.H. Mekhemer a Vannia C. dos Santos b Karen Wilson b ⁎ Mohamed I. Zaki a a Chemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Minia University, El-Minia, 61519, Egypt Chemistry Department Faculty of Science Minia University El-Minia 61519 Egypt b European Bioenergy Research Institute, School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Aston University, Aston Triangle, Birmingham, B4 7ET, UK European Bioenergy Research Institute School of Engineering and Applied Sciences Aston University Aston Triangle Birmingham B4 7ET UK ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Solid acids are desirable heterogeneous catalysts for green chemistry, with zirconia and its sulfated analogues offering tunable Lewis/Brønsted character. A new route to sulfated ZrO2, and Al-substituted ZrO2 (SO4/AlxZrO2), via carbonization and calcination of metal citrate gels and their subsequent sulfation by (NH4)2SO4 is reported. Structural and acidic properties of these materials were characterized by XRD, Raman, XPS, TGA-MS, N2 porosimetry, and propylamine and pyridine titration. Parent and sulfated materials all adopted the tetragonal zirconia phase, with Al-substitution (evidenced by contraction of the zirconia lattice parameter) at between 0.38–3.50wt% increasing the surface area but decreasing acid strength, accompanied by an overall increase in total acid site loading and Lewis character. Low Al concentrations enhance α-pinene isomerization activity by up to 50% due to the increased acid site loading, however the Turnover Frequency (TOF) remained constant indicating a common active site. The TOF decreased for Al concentrations >3.5wt% due to a further fall in acid strength, manifest as higher selectivity to polycyclic versus monocyclic products. Keywords Citrate mediated sol-gel Sulfated zirconia Terpenes α-pinene Solid acidity 1 Introduction Zirconia is a promising material for applications in catalysis [1,2], due to its tunable acid/base character, redox properties, and excellent chemical and thermal stability, which are also exploited for ceramic and optical applications [3–5]. Since Hino first reported sulfated zirconia as a superacidic material [6], various catalytic reactions have been explored and reviewed [7–9]. Many attempts have been reported to enhance the stability and catalytic activity of sulfated zirconias by addition of metals including Fe [10–12], Mn [10,11], Cr [13], Ce, [14], Al [15], and Ga [15], or Pt [10,11]. Incorporation of small amounts of Al into zirconia prior to sulfation increased activity and stability for n-butane isomerization [16,17], attributed to an increased concentration of intermediate strength acid sites (associated with Al-O-Zr centers [16]) and acid site loading and surface area [18]. The method of Al incorporation within the zirconia lattice is critical to their performance [19], with wet impregnation of γ-alumina with Zr(SO4)2·4H2O [20,21], sol-gel [22], and co-precipitation routes [23], explored. However, preparation of a homogenous mixed metal oxide is often hampered by segregation of the constituent alumina and zirconia phases, as observed for sol-gel methods employing (often costly) alkoxide precursors wherein rapid hydrolysis to the hydroxides promote discrete oxide formation [24]. The use of chelating agents such as citric acid to control the aqueous hydrolysis of metal salts is an alternative and attractive route to the controlled synthesis of mixed metal oxides from low cost precursors [24]. Citric acid may also serve as a fuel for the subsequent precursor decomposition, resulting in the genesis of a high surface area porous material, and hence is termed sol-gel combustion. Combustion methods are widely used in ceramic and composite manufacture, being rapid, low-cost and energy-efficient syntheses [25], and hence exploited to control the morphology of metastable materials under ambient conditions [26]. In-situ generation of water-soluble metal complexes from the reaction of aluminium nitrate and zirconium oxychloride with citric acid [27] is reported as a simple route to prepare Zr-doped alumina with 5–20wt% ZrO2. However, there are no reports of sulfated Al-substituted ZrO2 (SO4/AlxZrO2) prepared by this method [16]. Here we report the citric acid-mediated sol-gel combustion synthesis of highly crystalline and dispersed tetragonal ZrO2 nanoparticles isomorphically substituted with up to 3.5wt% Al, and their subsequent sulfation. Sulfated zirconias are efficient solid acid catalysts for the isomerization of alpha-pinene, an important terpene employed in fragrance and flavourings [28], and previous studies have identified strong acid sites as favourable for monocyclic products (e.g. limonene) with weaker acid sites favouring polycyclics (e.g. camphene) [29,30]. Our new synthetic approach facilitates the formation of uniform Al-substituted nanoparticles with enhanced activity, with the potential to tune acidity and hence selectivity towards monocyclic versus polycyclic products. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts synthesis Al-substituted zirconia was prepared via citrate-mediated sol-gel combustion [27,31]. Appropriate quantities of zirconium oxychloride (ZrOCl2·9H2O; 99% Research-Lab Fine Chem Industries/India) and aluminium nitrate (Al(NO3)3·3H2O; 98% Pacegrove Ltd/UK) were dissolved in 100mL of distilled water to achieve final Al loadings spanning 0–4wt%. To this mixture, 100mL of aqueous citric acid (C6H8O7·H2O; 99% Loba Chemie Pvt. Ltd/India) was added, with the acid concentration equimolar to the total metal content of the salt solution. The resulting mixture was held at 85°C and stirred until almost complete evaporation of the solvent and a glassy gel was formed. This gel was dried at 200°C in air, and the resulting solid residue manually ground in an agate mortar, then carbonized at 450°C for 15min (20°C/min), and then calcined at 600°C for 3h (5°C/min) under static air. The resulting zirconias were ground to ≤200μm, and subsequently sulfated via wet-impregnation (5mL/g zirconia) with appropriate concentrations of aqueous ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4; 99.5% Merck/Germany) to achieve 2wt%-S final loadings. The resulting slurry was stirred overnight, and excess water then evaporated at 90°C for 24h. The dried solid residue was manually ground in an agate mortar before calcination at 550°C for 3h (5°C/min). 2.2 Catalyst characterization Specific surface areas were determined by N2 physisorption employing the BET method [32] on samples outgassed at 200°C for 1h, using a Quantachrome Nova 2200 porosimeter. Net surface charge was approximated by determining the zero-charge point pH value (pHzcp) of solid particles suspended in deionized water (100mg/20mL) after 2h stirring at room temperature using a Jenway 3305pH meter. Sulfur content was determined on a Thermo-Scientific Flash 2000 CHNS-O analyser (CE Instruments Ltd., Wigan, UK). Al content was determined by ICP-OES using a Thermos-Scientific iCAP 7000 series elemental analyser after sample digestion using a CEM Discover SP-D microwave (5mL HNO3 and 5mL HCl at 200°C followed by dilution with 10% HNO3). Thermal analysis was performed using a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC1 Star TGA analyzer in conjunction with a Pfeiffer Vacuum Omnistar quadrupole mass spectrometer. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was measured using a JEOL JSX-60PA diffractometer equipped with Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (0.15418nm, 40kV and 30mA) between 2θ=4–100°. The crystalline phases were identified by comparison with relevant literature [29]. Lattice parameters were obtained using the following equations [33]: λ = 2 d ( h k l ) sin θ 1 d 2 = h 2 + k 2 a 2 + l 2 c 2 where d(hkl) is the distance between crystal planes of (hkl), λ the X-ray wavelength, θ the diffraction angle of crystal plane (hkl), hkl the crystal plane indices, and a and c are the lattice parameters of tetragonal zirconia (t-ZrO2). Laser Raman spectroscopy was performed on a Renishaw InVia Raman Microscope with an excitation wavelength of 532nm. The laser beam power was 10mW and spectra were the average of 50 scans. Surface compositions were determined by XPS using a Kratos Axis HSi spectrometer equipped with a charge neutralizer, monochromated Al Kα source (1486.7eV) and magnetic focusing lens. Spectra were recorded at normal emission with a pass energy of 40eV under a vacuum of 1.3×10−11 kPa; binding energies were referenced to adventitious carbon at 284.6eV, with peak fitting undertaken using CasaXPS version 2.3.15. Ex- and in-situ Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were measured on a Mattson Thermal Products Genesis II spectrometer using WinFirst Lite software. Spectra were recorded at 4000–400cm−1 averaged over 20 scans at 4cm−1 resolution. Ex-situ IR spectra were recorded of 1wt% samples diluted in KBr as self-supporting discs. In-situ IR spectra were recorded using a bespoke Pyrex IR cell equipped with CaF2 windows, similar to that described by Peri and Hannan [29]. In pyridine adsorption/desorption experiments, a self-supporting wafer (ca. 25mg sample/cm2) was: (i) mounted inside the cell; (ii) heated in a stream of 50cm3 O2/min at 400°C for 30min; (iii) degassed at 400°C for 30min; and (iv) cooled to room temperature under dynamic vacuum. Spectra were recorded of the sample before and after 5min exposure to 10Torr of pyridine vapour and subsequent degassing at room temperature and 100°C. Difference spectra of adsorbed pyridine species were obtained by subtraction of appropriate background spectrum. Pyridine vapour was admitted into the cell from the liquid (Specpure BDH) after outgassing via in-line freeze pump-thaw cycles. Temperature-programmed decomposition of propylamine to propene and NH3 via the Hoffman elimination reaction was employed to quantify acid loading and strength. n-Propylamine (≥99% Sigma Aldrich) was added to samples which were dried for 2h, with physisorbed propylamine then removed by degassing at 30°C overnight in vacuo. Samples were heated in the TGA-MS under flowing N2 (30cm3min−1) from 40 to 1000°C at a ramp rate of 10°C/min. 2.3 Catalytic activity α-pinene isomerization was performed under stirred batch conditions and atmospheric pressure in a Radleys Carousel reaction station in a 25mL glass tube reactor. Reactions were conducted using 63mmol of α-pinene, 0.25g of air-exposed catalyst, and 0.2cm3 of tetradecane as an internal standard at 85°C. Reaction profiles were obtained via periodic sampling and analysis using a Shimadzu GC-2010 plus gas chromatograph. Initial rates were determined from the linear portion of the conversion profile. Product selectivity was determined using appropriate reactant and product response factors derived from multipoint calibration curves. Conversion, selectivity, and mass balances were calculated as shown below: C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = [ α -pinene ] t = 0 - [ α -pinene ] t = i [ α -pinene ] t = 0 × 100 S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = [ p r o d u c t ] t = i [ α -pinene ] t = 0 - [ α -pinene ] t = i × 100 Catalyst reuse was evaluated by performing two recycle reactions using the 1.10wt% SO4/AlxZrO2 catalyst. After each 6h reaction, the spent catalyst was recovered by filtration, washed with anhydrous hexane and re-calcined at 500°C for 1h in static air. To evaluate the contribution of homogeneous catalysis due to possible sulfur leaching, an additional test was performed in which a 1.10wt% SO4/AlxZrO2 catalyst was removed from the reaction after 1h by hot filtration, and the supernatant monitored for a further 5h to identify any further reaction in the absence of catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Successful synthesis of a family of SO4/AlxZrO2 materials with increasing Al content was first verified by ICP-OES and CHNS analysis. Table 1 shows that the Al content increased systematically from 0 to 3.5wt% across the sulfated family, while CHNS revealed that all samples possessed similar S levels of 1.49–1.59wt%. The BET surface area increased with Al doping from 50m2/g for the pure zirconia, to 78m2/g for the 3.5wt% Al sample. XRD measurements revealed (110), (200), (101) and (211) reflections characteristic of pure t-zirconia (JCPDS card no. 88–1007) for both pure and Al-substituted sulfated zirconias (Fig. 1 a), with no evidence for Al phase separation. Al doping decreased the average crystallite size (Table S1) and shifted the principal diffraction peak at 30° to higher angle, consistent with a monotonic decrease in the lattice parameter of t-ZrO2 (Table S2) and evidencing the formation of a solid solution with Al3+ cations (0.5Å) isomorphically substituting for Zr4+ (0.84Å) in the zirconia lattice. Lattice contraction is predominantly observed through a shortening along the c axis (Fig. 1 b, Table S2), similar to that observed for Al-substituted ZrO2 nanoparticles prepared by chemical vapour synthesis [34], although in the latter case Al3+ substitution into the fluorite-type zirconia induced a progressive transformation from tetragonal to cubic symmetry. Raman spectroscopy of SO4/AlxZrO2 provides complimentary phase information to XRD [35] with lattice vibrations arising from t-ZrO2 and m-ZrO2 highlighted in Fig. 2 based on the assignments of Zyuzin et al. [36] In all cases, strong bands characteristic of t-ZrO2 were observed, with weak bands from m-ZrO2 only observed in the absence of Al, confirming stabilization of the tetragonal phase by aluminium. Surface composition of SO4/AlxZrO2 were determined by XPS (Table 2 ), which evidences both systematic Al incorporation, and a common degree of surface sulfation. The surface S and Al loadings are almost double that derived from bulk elemental analysis, indicating a degree of surface segregation (the former is expected since sulfation was performed post-synthesis). High resolution XP spectra confirm Zr 3d, S 2p, O 1s and Al 2p binding energies consistent with literature values for Al doped sulfated zirconia prepared by co-precipitation [37,38]. The Al 2p envelope binding energy remained constant at 74.5eV for all SO4/AlxZrO2 samples (Fig. S1a), slightly higher than that for pure Al2O3 (74.14–74.30eV [39]) and consistent with location of Al ions within the ZrO2 lattice. The S 2p envelope (Fig. S1b) was also independent of Al loading, with a constant binding energy of 169.2eV indicative of surface sulfate. [29] In contrast, Zr 3d spectra (Fig. S2) exhibit a small shift to lower binding upon Al incorporation >2.45wt%, as expected for Zr4+ cations proximate to Al3+ ions. Thermal analysis revealed the presence of two distinct sulfate species which decomposed at 617°C and 840°C, attributed to persulfate (S2O8 2−) and isolated surface sulfates respectively (Fig. 3 a) [40]. Al incorporation favors the formation of isolated sulfate species (Fig. 3 b, Table S3), presumably reflecting the concomitant increase in surface area and hence sulfate dispersion. Ex-situ IR spectra of sulfated zirconia in the absence of Al reveals three strong absorption maxima at 582, 506 and 444cm−1 (Fig. 4 ) assigned to Zr-O bond vibrations in t-ZrO2 lattice [41], and a weak band 733cm−1 characteristic of ZrO bond vibrations in m-ZrO2 lattice [41,42]. Several weak bands at 1240, 1195, 1140, 1044, 995 and 973cm−1 were also observed characteristic of ν SO and ν SO vibrations in surface sulfate species [43,44], in addition to a weak absorption at 1621cm−1 due to δOH vibrations of physisorbed water [45]. Al substitution into the zirconia lattice weakened the sulfate absorptions at 1195, 1044, 995 and 973cm−1, while those at 1240 and 1140cm−1 remain, accompanied by the emergence of two new bands at 1271 and 1071cm−1. The four bands at 1195, 1044, 995 and 973cm−1 are therefore attributed to persulfate species, while those favored by Al incorporation (1271, 1240, 1140 and 1071cm−1) are attributed to isolated sulfate. 3.2 Surface acidity In-situ IR spectra of chemisorbed pyridine on SO4/AlxZrO2 (Fig. 5 ) reveals the presence of Brønsted (1639 and 1540cm−1) and Lewis acid (1610cm−1 and 1444cm−1) sites for all samples [46]. The relative intensity of Brønsted to Lewis acid bands (IB:IL) decreased as a function of Al content (Table S4), [18] indicating that substitution of Al3+ ions into the zirconia lattice is accompanied by the formation of oxygen vacancies. The total acid site density was proportional to the degree of Al-substitution, presumably mirroring the increase in surface area. The increased Lewis acidity of Al-substituted sulfate zirconia (Fig. 6 a) was accompanied by a concomitant decrease in acid strength as determined from the desorption temperature for reactively-formed propene shown in Fig. 6 b and Fig. S3 (which rose from 398→421°C) and the pHzcp (which rose from 2.89 to 3.93, Table S4). 4 Catalytic activity The catalytic performance of SO4/AlxZrO2 was subsequently assessed towards α-pinene isomerization, an acid catalyzed reaction that occurs via two competing pathways (Scheme 1 ). Weaker solid acids favor polycyclic products through ring rearrangement [47], with camphene typically the dominant product, whereas stronger acids favor CC bond cleavage to form monocyclic products typified by limonene. The twelve different isomers of α-pinene identified in the present work re shown in Fig. S4. In the absence of catalyst, negligible α-pinene conversion was observed (1.12% after 6h). SO4/AlxZrO2 reactivity is shown in Fig. 7 , for which an increase in α-pinene conversion, and concomitant activity, was observed with increasing Al content up to 2.45wt%, above which additional Al lowered performance. The promotion at low Al concentrations is attributed to a purely geometric effect associated with increased surface area and total acid site loading. This hypothesis is supported by the constant TOF (120±20h−1, Fig. 8 ) observed for 0–2.45wt% SO4/AlxZrO2 catalysts. The decreased conversion and TOF for the highest 3.5wt% SO4/AlxZrO2 sample cannot be attributed to a geometric effect since this catalyst possesses the highest acid site density (253μmolg−1), and hence must reflect a combination of its weaker acid strength and greater Lewis acid character; pure Lewis acid catalysts are reported inactive for α-pinene isomerization [47,48]. The fall in acid strength for the highest degree of Al substitution is also manifest by a slight increase in selectivity to polycyclics as shown in Fig. S5-6 and Table S5. The stability of the most active 1.1wt% SO4/AlxZrO2 catalyst was subsequently investigated through recycling and hot filtration tests. The supernatant was inactive towards α-pinene conversion following removal of the catalyst after 1h reaction, as shown in Fig. S7, indicating negligible contribution to the observed catalysis from any leached sulfur species. Significant catalyst deactivation was observed in the absence of a high temperature regeneration step, however, re-calcination at 500°C recovered >50% of the original activity for α-pinene isomerization (Fig. S8). The activity loss for the regenerated catalyst is attributed to partial loss of sulfate groups (∼15% of the initial concentration, from CHNS analysis, Table S6) due to leaching during the first reaction cycle (although the supernatant containing this leached S was inactive, as stated above), and site-blocking by strongly bound organic residues. However, catalyst activity remained stable at 50% of the initial value over subsequent recycle experiments. This work demonstrates the versatility of citric acid-mediated sol-gel combustion synthesis for fine tuning the surface acidic properties of sulphated mixed metal oxides, paving the way for further applications of this preparative route in catalysis. 5 Conclusions Isomorphic substitution of Al into tetragonal zirconia nanoparticles (∼8nm) was achieved via a citrate-mediated sol-gel synthesis, and subsequent carbonization and calcination. Wet impregnation by (NH4)2SO4 and further thermal processing yielded high area Al-substituted sulfated zirconia (SO4/AlxZrO2). Increasing the degree of Al substitution into the zirconia lattice resulted in a monotonic increase in surface area, acid site loading and Lewis character, and concomitant decrease in acid strength, accompanied by the transformation of surface persulfate to more thermally stable isolated sulfate species. Incorporation of Al at levels <2.45wt% enhanced activity for α-pinene isomerization, attributed to the superior acid site loading. Higher Al concentrations favor weaker, Lewis acid sites, resulting in lower activity and increased selectivity to polycyclic isomers. coredata.dc:description: Solid acids are desirable heterogeneous catalysts for green chemistry, with zirconia and its sulfated analogues offering tunable Lewis/Brønsted character. A new route to sulfated ZrO2, and Al-substituted ZrO2 (SO4/AlxZrO2), via carbonization and calcination of metal citrate gels and their subsequent sulfation by (NH4)2SO4 is reported. Structural and acidic properties of these materials were characterized by XRD, Raman, XPS, TGA-MS, N2 porosimetry, and propylamine and pyridine titration. Parent and sulfated materials all adopted the tetragonal zirconia phase, with Al-substitution (evidenced by contraction of the zirconia lattice parameter) at between 0.38–3.50wt% increasing the surface area but decreasing acid strength, accompanied by an overall increase in total acid site loading and Lewis character. Low Al concentrations enhance α-pinene isomerization activity by up to 50% due to the increased acid site loading, however the Turnover Frequency (TOF) remained constant indicating a common active site. The TOF decreased for Al concentrations >3.5wt% due to a further fall in acid strength, manifest as higher selectivity to polycyclic versus monocyclic products.
coredata.dc:title: Citrate-mediated sol–gel synthesis of Al-substituted sulfated zirconia catalysts for α-pinene isomerization
